## Custom functions
Some of the functions in this study were adopted from **[Atkinson et al. (2022)](https://doi.org/10.1111/ele.14025)**, **[Lopez et al. (2022)](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.211738911)** and **[Pottier et al. (2022)](https://doi.org/10.1111/ele.14083)**.

```{r}

get_pred1 <- function(model, mod = " ") {
  name <- name <- firstup(as.character(stringr::str_replace(row.names(model$beta), 
                                                            mod, "")))
  len <- length(name)
  
  if (len != 1) {
    newdata <- matrix(NA, ncol = len, nrow = len)
    for (i in 1:len) {
      pos <- which(model$X[, i] == 1)[[1]]
      newdata[, i] <- model$X[pos, ]
    }
    pred <- metafor::predict.rma(model, newmods = newdata)
  } else {
    pred <- metafor::predict.rma(model)
  }
  estimate <- pred$pred
  lowerCL <- pred$ci.lb
  upperCL <- pred$ci.ub
  lowerPR <- pred$cr.lb
  upperPR <- pred$cr.ub
  
  table <- tibble(name = factor(name, levels = name, labels = name), estimate = estimate, 
                  lowerCL = lowerCL, upperCL = upperCL, pval = model$pval, lowerPR = lowerPR, 
                  upperPR = upperPR)
}


I2 <- function(model, method = c("Wolfgang", "Shinichi")) {
    
    ## evaluate choices
    method <- match.arg(method)
    
    # Wolfgang's method
    if (method == "Wolfgang") {
        W <- solve(model$V)
        X <- model.matrix(model)
        P <- W - W %*% X %*% solve(t(X) %*% W %*% X) %*% t(X) %*% W
        I2_total <- sum(model$sigma2)/(sum(model$sigma2) + (model$k - model$p)/sum(diag(P)))
        I2_each <- model$sigma2/(sum(model$sigma2) + (model$k - model$p)/sum(diag(P)))
        names(I2_each) = paste0("I2_", model$s.names)
        
        # putting all together
        I2s <- c(I2_total = I2_total, I2_each)
        
        # or my way
    } else {
        # sigma2_v = typical sampling error variance
        sigma2_v <- sum(1/model$vi) * (model$k - 1)/(sum(1/model$vi)^2 - sum((1/model$vi)^2))
        I2_total <- sum(model$sigma2)/(sum(model$sigma2) + sigma2_v)  #s^2_t = total variance
        I2_each <- model$sigma2/(sum(model$sigma2) + sigma2_v)
        names(I2_each) = paste0("I2_", model$s.names)
        
        # putting all together
        I2s <- c(I2_total = I2_total, I2_each)
    }
    return(I2s)
}

my.orchard<- function (object, mod = "1", group, data, xlab, N = "none", 
    alpha = 0.5, angle = 90, cb = FALSE, k = TRUE, g = TRUE, 
    trunk.size = 4, branch.size = 1.5, twig.size = 0.8, whisker, transfm = c("none", # increased point size, branch size, and added a whisker argument
        "tanh"), condition.lab = "Condition", legend.pos = "bottom.right", k.pos = c("right", 
        "left")) 
{
    transfm <- match.arg(transfm)
    if (any(class(object) %in% c("rma.mv", "rma"))) {
        if (mod != "1") {
            results <- orchaRd::mod_results(object, mod, group, 
                data)
        }
        else {
            results <- orchaRd::mod_results(object, mod = "1", 
                group, data)
        }
    }
    if (any(class(object) %in% c("orchard"))) {
        results <- object
    }
    mod_table <- results$mod_table
    data <- results$data
    data$moderator <- factor(data$moderator, levels = mod_table$name, 
        labels = mod_table$name)
    data$scale <- (1/sqrt(data[, "vi"]))
    legend <- "Precision (1/SE)"
    if (any(N != "none")) {
        data$scale <- N
        legend <- "Sample Size (N)"
    }
    if (transfm == "tanh") {
        cols <- sapply(mod_table, is.numeric)
        mod_table[, cols] <- Zr_to_r(mod_table[, cols])
        data$yi <- Zr_to_r(data$yi)
        label <- xlab
    }
    else {
        label <- xlab
    }
    mod_table$K <- as.vector(by(data, data[, "moderator"], 
        function(x) length(x[, "yi"])))
    mod_table$g <- as.vector(num_studies(data, moderator, stdy)[, 
        2])
    group_no <- length(unique(mod_table[, "name"]))
    cbpl <- c("#88CCEE", "#CC6677", "#DDCC77", 
        "#117733", "#332288", "#AA4499", "#44AA99", 
        "#999933", "#882255", "#661100", "#6699CC", 
        "#888888", "#E69F00", "#56B4E9", "#009E73", 
        "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7", 
        "#999999")
    if (names(mod_table)[2] == "condition") {
        condition_no <- length(unique(mod_table[, "condition"]))
        plot <- ggplot2::ggplot() + ggbeeswarm::geom_quasirandom(data = data, 
            ggplot2::aes(y = yi, x = moderator, size = scale, 
                colour = moderator), alpha = alpha) + ggplot2::geom_hline(yintercept = 0, 
            linetype = 2, colour = "black", alpha = alpha) + 
            ggplot2::geom_linerange(data = mod_table, ggplot2::aes(x = name, 
                ymin = lowerCL, ymax = upperCL), size = branch.size, 
                position = ggplot2::position_dodge2(width = 0.3)) + 
            ggplot2::geom_pointrange(data = mod_table, ggplot2::aes(y = estimate, 
                x = name, ymin = lowerPR, ymax = upperPR, shape = as.factor(condition), 
                fill = name), size = twig.size, position = ggplot2::position_dodge2(width = 0.3), 
                fatten = trunk.size) + ggplot2::scale_shape_manual(values = 20 + 
            (1:condition_no)) + ggplot2::coord_flip() + ggplot2::theme_bw() + 
            ggplot2::guides(fill = "none", colour = "none") + 
            ggplot2::theme(legend.position = c(0, 1), legend.justification = c(0, 
                1)) + ggplot2::theme(legend.title = ggplot2::element_text(size = 9)) + 
            ggplot2::theme(legend.direction = "horizontal") + 
            ggplot2::theme(legend.background = ggplot2::element_blank()) + 
            ggplot2::labs(y = label, x = "", size = legend) + 
            ggplot2::labs(shape = condition.lab) + ggplot2::theme(axis.text.y = ggplot2::element_text(size = 10, 
            colour = "black", hjust = 0.5, angle = angle))
    }
    else {
        plot <- ggplot2::ggplot() + ggbeeswarm::geom_quasirandom(data = data, 
            ggplot2::aes(y = yi, x = moderator, size = scale, 
                fill = moderator), alpha = alpha, width=0.4, pch=21, stroke=1.1, col="black") + # Change point shape (21, with black borders)
            ggplot2::geom_hline(yintercept = 0, 
            linetype = 2, colour = "black", alpha = 0.3, lwd=1.3) + # Change thickness 0 line
            ggplot2::geom_errorbar(data = mod_table, ggplot2::aes(x = name, 
                ymin = lowerCL, ymax = upperCL), size = branch.size, width= whisker) + # Added variable whisker size
            ggplot2::geom_pointrange(data = mod_table, ggplot2::aes(y = estimate, 
                x = name, ymin = lowerPR, ymax = upperPR, fill = name), 
                size = twig.size, fatten = trunk.size, shape = 23, stroke=2.2) + # Change point shape
            scale_size_continuous(range = c(1, 14))+ # change point scaling
            ggplot2::coord_flip() + 
            ggplot2::theme_bw() + 
            ggplot2::guides(fill = "none", colour = "none") + 
            ggplot2::theme(text=element_text(size=26, colour="black"))+ # Change font size
            ggplot2::theme(legend.title = ggplot2::element_text(size = 16)) + # Increased font legend title
            ggplot2::theme(legend.text = ggplot2::element_text(size = 14)) +
            ggplot2::theme(legend.direction = "horizontal") + 
            ggplot2::theme(legend.background = ggplot2::element_blank()) + 
            ggplot2::labs(y = label, x = "", size = legend) + 
            ggplot2::theme(axis.text.y = ggplot2::element_text(size = 20, 
                colour = "black", hjust = 0.5, angle = angle)) + # Increased size title axis label
            ggplot2::theme(axis.text.x = ggplot2::element_text(size = 20, colour = "black")) + # Increase size axis ticks
            ggplot2::theme(panel.border = element_rect(colour = "black", fill=NA, size=1.3))
            
    }
    if (legend.pos == "bottom.right") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = c(1, 
            0), legend.justification = c(1, 0))
    }
    else if (legend.pos == "bottom.left") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = c(0, 
            0), legend.justification = c(0, 0))
    }
    else if (legend.pos == "top.right") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = c(1, 
            1), legend.justification = c(1, 1))
    }
    else if (legend.pos == "top.left") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = c(0, 
            1), legend.justification = c(0, 1))
    }
    else if (legend.pos == "top.out") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "top")
    }
    else if (legend.pos == "bottom.out") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "bottom")
    }
    if (cb == TRUE) {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::scale_fill_manual(values = cbpl) + 
            ggplot2::scale_colour_manual(values = cbpl)
    }
    if (k == TRUE && g == FALSE && k.pos == "right") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::annotate("text", y = (max(data$yi) + 
            (max(data$yi) * 0.1)), x = (seq(1, group_no, 1) + 
            0), label = paste("italic(k)==", mod_table$K[1:group_no]), # Size changed to 5.5
            parse = TRUE, hjust = "right", size = 6.5)
    }
    else if (k == TRUE && g == FALSE && k.pos == "left") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::annotate("text", y = (min(data$yi) + 
            (min(data$yi) * 0.1)), x = (seq(1, group_no, 1) + 
            0), label = paste("italic(k)==", mod_table$K[1:group_no]), 
            parse = TRUE, hjust = "left", size = 6.5) # Size changed to 5.5
    }
    else if (k == TRUE && g == TRUE && k.pos == "right") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::annotate("text", y = (max(data$yi) + 
            (max(data$yi) * 0.1)), x = (seq(1, group_no, 1) + 
            0), label = paste("italic(k)==", mod_table$K[1:group_no], 
            " (", mod_table$g[1:group_no], ")"), 
            parse = TRUE, hjust = "right", size = 6.5) # Size changed to 5.5
    }
    else if (k == TRUE && g == TRUE && k.pos == "left") {
        plot <- plot + ggplot2::annotate("text", y = (min(data$yi) + 
            (min(data$yi) * 0.1)), x = (seq(1, group_no, 1) + 
            0), label = paste("italic(k)==", mod_table$K[1:group_no], 
            " (", mod_table$g[1:group_no], ")"), 
            parse = TRUE, hjust = "left", size = 6.5) # Size changed to 5.5
    }
    return(plot)
}
```

# Literature search

A comprehensive literature search for studies evaluating individual and combined impacts of co-occuring invasive species was conduvted on the Web of Science (WoS) core collection platform on 11 June, 2022  (Timespan: all years) using the search string: (("Co-occurring inva\*" OR "Co-occurring exotic" OR "Co-occurring non-native" OR "Co-occurring alien" OR "Co-occurring introduced" OR "Co-occurring non-indigenous" OR "Cooccurring inva\*" OR "Cooccurring exotic" OR "Cooccurring non-native" OR "Co-occurring non native" OR "Cooccurring non native" OR "Cooccurring alien" OR "Cooccurring introduced" OR "Cooccurring non-indigenous" OR "Co-occurring non indigenous" OR "Concurring inva\*" OR "Concurring exotic" OR "Concurring non-native" OR "Concurring non native" OR "Concurring alien" OR "Concurring introduced" OR "Concurring non-indigenous" OR "Concurring non indigenous" OR "multi\* inva\*" OR "multi\* exotic" OR "multi\* non-native" OR " multi\* non native" OR " multi\* alien" OR "multi\* introduced" OR "multi\* non-indigenous" OR " multi\* non indigenous" OR "Co-inva\*") AND ("impact\*" OR "effect\*" OR "modif\*" OR "change\*" OR "influence\*") AND ("richness" OR "diversity" OR "community structure\*" OR "community assemblage\*" OR "ecosystem structure" OR "ecosystem function\*" OR "population\*" OR "composition\*" OR "ecosystem process\*" OR "ecosystem pool\*" OR "ecosystem flux\*" OR "competition\*" OR "evenness" OR "biodiversity" OR "biological diversity" OR "abundance\*" OR "biomass" OR "producti\*" OR "growth" OR "cover" OR "densit\*" OR "species abundance distribution\*" OR "biogeochemical" OR "nutrient cycl\*" OR "cycling of nutrient\*" OR "nutrient dynamics" OR "nutrient flux\*" OR "nutrient pool\*" OR "flux\* of nutrient\*" OR "carbon" OR "nitrogen" OR "phosphorous" OR "pH" OR "organic matter" OR "decomposition" OR "litter" OR "soil" OR "hydrolog\*" OR "water"  OR "resource\*" OR "mycorrhiza" OR "bacteria" OR "fung\*" OR "microb\*")). The retrieved literature was screened for possibility of duplicate and irrelevant studies using the revtools package **[(Westgate, 2019)](https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1374)**. Second, using the included articles from WoS as seed, we searched the backward references and forward citations of these selected articles on July 17, 2022, using the citationchaser package **[(Haddaway et al., 2022)](https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1563)** to identify additional articles that might have been missed in the WoS search. Third, we also searched references and citations of previously published reviews on invasive species interactions and invasional meltdown (**[Simberloff & Von Holle, 1999](https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1010086329619)**; **[Ballari et al., 2016](https://peerj.com/articles/2029/)**; **[Jackson, 2015](https://doi.org/10.1890/15-0171.1)**; **[Kuebbing et al., 2013](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biocon.2013.01.009)**; **[Kuebbing & Nunez, 2015](https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.12711)**; **[2016](https://www.nature.com/articles/nplants2016134)**) to obtain additional relevant studies. The numbers of articles retrieved during the literature searches and those included as well as excluded at each stage of screeming process are shown in figure 1 (PRISMA flow diagram). 

All the screening was performed by the lead author **RA**.

  
We followed reporting guidelines outlined in the PRISMA-EcoEvo checklist **[(O'Dea et al., 2021)](https://doi.org/10.1111/brv.12721)**.

## The  co-invasion impact dataset

### Table of the dataset

The dataset used for our meta-analysis and vote counting is presented below along with the discription of each variables included (variables not included in our meta-analysis or vote counting are shown by *).

```{r data-set}
# getting the data into R emvironment
full_data<- read.csv("data/co-invasion_data_extracted.csv")

# making a scrollable table of dataset
kable(full_data, "html") %>%
 kable_styling("striped", position = "left") %>%
 scroll_box(width = "850px", height = "300px")
```

`Citation*`:  Reference of the paper included.

`PR.ID`: Unique ID for each paper included.

`Year`: Publication year of the paper.

`ES.ID`: Unique ID for each row of data (i.e., effect size or observation).

`CHT.ID`: Unique ID for each cohort (i.e., observation from same experimental plot, locality etc).

`Ecosystem_type`: Ecosystem were study was conducted.

`Longitude`: Longitude of the location were study was conducted in decimal degrees.

`Latitude`: Latitude of the location were study was conducted decimal degrees.

`Study_design`: Method of performing the study (i.e., Observational or experimental).

`Study*`: Nature of study, (i.e., whether aquatic or terrestrial) 

`Continent`: Name of the continent in which the study was carried out.

`Region*`: Name of the locality in which the study was carried out.

`Country*`: Name of the country in which the study was carried out.

`Climate*`: Main climate of the region in which the study was carried out.

`Source`: Location in the paper where from the data was collected (i.e., Text, Table or Figure).

`Variable*`: Name of the parameter for which data was extracted.

`Impact_type`: Classification of the parameter (i.e. variables) into broader response class.


`Level_ecological_organization`: Classification of the parameter (i.e. variables) based on hierarchical organisation.

`Invader_1*`: Identity of the first invader in co-invaded condition.

`Invader_2*`: Identity of the second invader in co-invaded condition.

`Interacting_taxon`: Identity of the interacting taxonomic class.

`Trohic_level*`: Position of the interacting taxons along food web.

`nI1`: Sample size in the invader 1 invaded plot.

`mI1`: Mean value of variable in the invader 1 invaded plot.

`sdI1`: Standard deviation of variable in the invader 1 invaded plot.

`nI2`: Sample size in the invader 2 invaded plot.

`mI2`: Mean value of variable in the invader 2 invaded plot.

`sdI2`: Standard deviation of variable in the invader 2 invaded plot.

`nI1_I2`: Sample size in the co-invaded plot (i.e. both invaders present ).

`mI1_I2`: Mean value of variable in the the co-invaded plot.

`sdI1_I2`: Standard deviation of variable in the the co-invaded plot.

`nC`: Sample size in the control (i.e., uninvaded) plot.

`mC`: Mean value of variable in the control plot.

`sdC`: Standard deviation of variable in the control  plot.

`num_shared_control`: Number of times the control was shared in the study.

`N_control_sc`: Modified sample size for the control plot to account for the shared control dependence (calculated by dividing overall sample size for the shared control group by the total number of shared controls).

### Levels of Ecological organization and response classes
We classified each of the studied ecological variable into three levels of ecological organization based on whether impacts are related to species, resident communities, or ecosystem properties and functioning. # Meta-analysis
## Calculating effect sizes

To quantify the combined effect for each observation in the dataset, we used the Hedges' *d* as an effect size estimator. Each of the calculated combined effect sizes was based on the difference between the actual observed net impact of co-invaders against a predicted additive outcome based on the sum of each invader's independent effects **[(Jackson et al., 2016)](https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.13028)**. For each of the included response variable (X), the predicted additive effect of the two invaders (p) from the four treatment groups (i.e., control (C), invader 1 (1), invader 2 (2) and both invaders 1 and 2 (12) was calculated as:
                      p = (X1-Xc) + (X2-Xc) + Xc

We also make use of the `make_VCV_matrix` function from the `metaAidR` package to calculate the variance-covariance matrix assuming a correlation of 0.5 for use in the meta-analytical model instead of the error term `vi` to overcome the dependence of sampling errors resulting from multiple outcomes **[(Noble et al., 2017)](https://doi.org/10.1111/mec.14031)**. This was considered because when more than one effect size is reported from the same experimental unit (cohort) (i.e., different metrics measured in the same quadrat or different nutrients estimated from the same soil sample), the sampling error of these effect sizes will be correlated. Also, in certain cases in our dataset, more than one treatment groups were compared to the same control group, the sampling error of the effect sizes is considered to be correlated. To overcome this dependence of sampling errors arising because of shared control problem, we calculated  a modified sample size (n) for shared control groups by dividing the original sample size of the control group by the number of shared controls and used the modified sample size for effect size calculation **[(Higgins et al., 2019)](https://training.cochrane.org/handbook/archive/v6)**.

```{r}

# import the data file
data_all <- read.csv("data/co-invasion_data_extracted.csv")

# remove cases from the data where control SD = 0,  that usually results in having vi=NA 
data<-data_all %>% filter(sdC != 0)

# Effect size calculation based on **[(Koricheva et al., 2013)](https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691137285/handbook-of-meta-analysis-in-ecology-and-evolution)** 

# Calculating J's for treatments    ## correction for small sample sizes
data$J_inv1 <- 1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1))
data$J_inv2 <- 1 - (3/(4*(data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1))
data$J_inv1_inv2 <- 1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1))

# S's for treatments   ## pooled SD
data$S_inv1 <- (sqrt ((data$nI1 - 1)*data$sdI1^2 + (data$N_control_sc - 1)*data$sdC^2)/(data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc - 2))
data$S_inv2 <- (sqrt ((data$nI2 - 1)*data$sdI2^2 + (data$N_control_sc - 1)*data$sdC^2)/(data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc - 2))
data$S_inv1_inv2 <- (sqrt ((data$nI1_I2 - 1)*data$sdI1_I2^2 + (data$N_control_sc - 1)*data$sdC^2)/(data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc - 2))

# ES's (d's) for treatments
data$d_inv1 <- (data$mI1 - data$mC) / data$S_inv1 *data$J_inv1
data$d_inv2 <- (data$mI2 - data$mC) / data$S_inv2 *data$J_inv2
data$d_inv1_inv2 <- (data$mI1_I2 - data$mC) / data$S_inv1_inv2 *data$J_inv1_inv2

# variance of ES's (sigma^2)
data$d_var_inv1 <- (1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1)))^2 * ((data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc - 2)/((data$nI1*data$N_control_sc/(data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc)) * (data$nI1 + data$N_control_sc - 4)))
data$d_var_inv2 <- (1 - (3/(4*(data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1)))^2 * ((data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc - 2)/((data$nI2*data$N_control_sc/(data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc)) * (data$nI2 + data$N_control_sc - 4)))
data$d_var_inv1_inv2 <- (1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc - 2) - 1)))^2 * ((data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc - 2)/((data$nI1_I2*data$N_control_sc/(data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc)) * (data$nI1_I2 + data$N_control_sc - 4)))

# Calculating Predicted Additive effect - from Jackson et al., 2016)
 
data$mean_pred_add <- (data$mI1 - data$mC) + (data$mI2 - data$mC) + data$mC

# Replacing impossible values with zero:
# which effect sizes are predicted to be negative?
test<-data[data$mean_pred_add<0,c("PR.ID","Impact_type","Level_ecological_organization","mC","mI1","mI2","mean_pred_add")]
#dim(test) 
#unique(test$Impact_type) # many of these are variable that can't be negative (e.g. abundance, richness, diversity, production etc)
 
# Replacing impossible negative values with zeros
## define by those where the "orginal" (without sign change) predicted additive is <0 but none of the treatment means are
data$mean_pred_add[data$mean_pred_add<0&data$mC>0&data$mI1>0&data$mI2>0&data$mI1_I2>0]<-0

# calculate pooled SD and n
data$SD_pred_add <- (sqrt ((data$nI1 - 1)*data$sdI1^2 + (data$nI2 - 1)*data$sdI2^2)/(data$nI1 + data$nI2 - 2))
data$n_pred_add <- data$nI1 + data$nI2

# calculate Hedges' *d* comparing  observed combined effect from co-invasion) to Predicted Additive
data$J_pred_add <- 1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add - 2) - 1))
data$S_pred_add <- (sqrt ((data$nI1_I2 - 1)*data$sdI1_I2^2 + (data$n_pred_add - 1)*data$SD_pred_add^2)/(data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add - 2))
data$d_pred_add <- (data$mI1_I2 - data$mean_pred_add) / data$S_pred_add *data$J_pred_add
data$d_var_pred_add <-(1 - (3/(4*(data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add  - 2) - 1)))^2 * ((data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add - 2)/((data$nI1_I2*data$n_pred_add/(data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add)) * (data$nI1_I2 + data$n_pred_add - 4)))

```

## Classifying interactions
Based on the framework from **[(Piggott et al., 2015)](https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.1465)**, and **[(Lopez et al., 2022)](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.211738911)**, we compared the observed combined effect  to the predicted additive effect. Interactions were considered additive if the observed combined effect was not significantly different from the predicted additive effect (i.e., 95% confidence intervals around Hedges' *d* overlapped zero), otherwise considered non-additive, In case of non-additivity, synergistic interactions occured when the observed combined effect  differed from the predicted additive effect and fell outside the range of values of the individual invader effects and the control, otherwise, they were classified as antagonistic. We further classified antagonistic and synergistic interactions based on whether the observed combined effect was more positive or negative than the predicted additive effec as: antagonistic (-), antagonistic (+), synergistic (-), and synergistic (+), where the + and - denotes the observed combined effect being more positive or negative than expected respectively (Fig. 2; Redrawn from **[(Lopez et al., 2022)](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.211738911)**)

**Figure 2 (main manuscript)**. Conceptual framework redrawn from **[Lopez et al. (2022)](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.211738911)** for classification of different interaction types based on the relationship between co-occuring invasive species individual effects (i.e., INV-1 and INV-2) and the predicted additive effect (i.e., sum of the individual invader effects), for cases where both co-invaders (i.e., INV-1 and INV-2) individual effects are in the same direction (a) and where the co-invaders (i.e., INV-1 and INV-2) individual effects are in opposite directions (b). Observed combined invader (INV-1 and INV-2) effects falling within the 95% confidence interval around the predicted additive effect are classified as additive. Effects that differ from the predicted additive (INV-1+INV-2) effect but fall within the range of the individual invader effects and the control are classified as antagonistic, while as those falling outside of this range are classified as synergistic. Antagonistic and synergistic effects are further classified as "+"  or "-" depending on whether the observed combined effect is more positive or more negative than the predicted additive effect. 
```{r}

# define confidence intervals for d_pred_add
data$d_CI_pred_add <- 1.96 * (sqrt(data$d_var_pred_add) / sqrt(data$n_pred_add))
data$d_lower_pred_add <- data$d_pred_add - data$d_CI_pred_add
data$d_higher_pred_add <- data$d_pred_add + data$d_CI_pred_add

# creating two columns here:
## one called, interaction_type, has Additive, Synergistic, Antagonistic effect
## second called, interaction_type_direction, has + or - sign for Synergistic and Antagonistic based on whether higher or lower than expected (specifically from Lopez et al., 2022)

# condition 1. is Hedges' *d* different from 0 (based on CI)? if not -> Additive interaction
data$interaction_type[data$d_lower_pred_add<=0 & data$d_higher_pred_add>=0] <- "Additive"
data$interaction_type_direction[data$d_lower_pred_add<=0 & data$d_higher_pred_add>=0] <- "Additive"

# condition 2. does Hedges' *d* fall outside bounds of control and treatments? if yes -> Synergistic interaction 
# for this, first define confidence intervals for d_inv1_inv2 to see whether they overlap the d's of any of the treatments or control (Piggott et al., 2015; Lopez et al., 2022)
data$d_CI_inv1_inv2 <- 1.96 * (sqrt(data$d_var_inv1_inv2) / sqrt(data$nI1_I2))
data$d_lower_inv1_inv2 <- data$d_inv1_inv2 - data$d_CI_inv1_inv2
data$d_higher_inv1_inv2 <- data$d_inv1_inv2 + data$d_CI_inv1_inv2

# next define synergies
data$interaction_type[data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>0 & data$d_lower_pred_add>0 & data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>data$d_inv1 & data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>data$d_inv2]<- "Synergistic"
data$interaction_type[data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<0 & data$d_higher_pred_add<0 & data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<data$d_inv1 & data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<data$d_inv2]<- "Synergistic"
data$interaction_type_direction[data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>0 & data$d_lower_pred_add>0 & data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>data$d_inv1 & data$d_lower_inv1_inv2>data$d_inv2]<- "Synergistic +"
data$interaction_type_direction[data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<0 & data$d_higher_pred_add<0 & data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<data$d_inv1 & data$d_higher_inv1_inv2<data$d_inv2]<- "Synergistic -"

# otherwise, Antagonistic
data$interaction_type_direction[data$d_lower_pred_add>0 & is.na(data$interaction_type)] <- "Antagonistic +"
data$interaction_type_direction[data$d_higher_pred_add<0 & is.na(data$interaction_type)] <- "Antagonistic -"
data$interaction_type[is.na(data$interaction_type)]<-"Antagonistic"

# tabulating interaction cateogories
#table(data$interaction_type)

# calculating proportions 
#table(data$interaction_type)/nrow(data)

# tabulating interaction cateogories by direction
#table(data$interaction_type_direction)

# calculating proportions 
#table(data$interaction_type_direction)/nrow(data)

# calculating percentage
round(table(data$interaction_type_direction)/nrow(data)*100, 2)
```


## Intercept only model
We conducted the intercept only meta-analytic model (i.e.  models) using the `rma.mv` function from the `metafor` package **[(Viechtbauer, 2010)](https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v036.i03)**. The `rma.mv`function allows us to incorporate variance-covariance matrices in the `V` term. We fitted two random effects i.e. `effect size ID` (ES.ID)  to measure the residual heterogeneity and `study ID` (PR.ID) to account for non-independence of multiple effect sizes originating within the same study.

```{r fig.height=5, fig.width=15, cache=TRUE}
# make variance covariance matrix
data <- data[order(data$CHT.ID), ]
data$vcv_0.5 <- make_VCV_matrix(data = data, V = "d_var_pred_add",
                              cluster = "CHT.ID", obs = "ES.ID",
                              type = "vcv", rho = 0.5)

# # intercept only meta-analytic model
hedges_d_full <- rma.mv(d_pred_add, vcv_0.5, random = list(~1 | PR.ID, ~1 | ES.ID), method = "REML", data = data)
full<-mod_results(hedges_d_full, mod = "1", data = data, group = "PR.ID")
# interaction types
int_plot<-data.frame(table(data$interaction_type_direction)) %>%
  mutate(interaction_type_direction=Var1, Prop = Freq/sum(Freq), x = "x")
int_plot$interaction_type_direction<-factor(int_plot$interaction_type_direction, levels = c("Synergistic +","Antagonistic +", "Additive", "Antagonistic -","Synergistic -"))

# making plots

p1 <- my.orchard(full, mod = "1", xlab = expression(paste("Mean effect size (Hedges' ", italic("d"), ")")), alpha = 0.1, data = data, group = "PR.ID",
           whisker = 0.02) # Display orchard plot

  
p2 <-ggplot(data = int_plot, aes(x =Prop, y = x, fill = interaction_type_direction)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack") +
  scale_fill_manual("Interaction Type", values = c("#BE3526", "#D8867D", "#DDDDDD", "#67A3C2","#016699")[5:1]) + # "breaks" flips order in legend
  theme_bw() +
  #geom_text(y=0.9, x=1.5, label = "B", size =10)+
  labs(x = "Interaction type (Proportion of cases)")+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", colour = "black"),  
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", colour = "black"),
        axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.title.y = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
        legend.position = c(.25,-.4), legend.direction = "horizontal",
        legend.title = element_text(size=15, face = "bold"), #change legend title font size
        legend.text = element_text(size=13, face = "bold"),
        plot.margin = margin(0.5, 0.5, 2, 1, "cm")) # top, right, bottom, left

(p1| p2) +plot_annotation(tag_prefix = "(", tag_levels = "a", tag_suffix = ")")
```
**Figure 3 (main manuscript).** The orchard plot showing the mean combined effect  (Hedge's *d* - central square) of co-invasion relative to the sum of individual effects, along with 95% confidence interval (thick black line) 95% prediction interval (thin black line), and observed effect sizes (coloured background points) with their size scaled by precision of estimate (1/SE). k denotes number of effect sizes (number of studies) (a) and the proportion of interaction types (b). 

**Table S6:** Overall mean combined effect along with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) and 95% prediction intervals.

```{r}
pred <- get_pred1(hedges_d_full, mod = "Int")


# Drawing a table for overall effect 
tibble(`Effect size` = ("Hedges' d"), 
       `Overall mean` = pred$estimate,
```

# Meta-regression models
In the present study, We conducted a number of univariate meta-regression models for the following recorded moderators to test our key research questions: **(a)**`Response class (i.e., Impact type`) **(b)** `Level_ecological_organization`, **(c)** `Ecosysyem_type`, **(d)** `Continent`, **(e)** `Taxnomic group` and **(f)**`Study_design`. Simply, these moderators help us to investigate whether the co-invasion effects varies with the studied variables.

# Publication bias

We used several proceedures as recommended **[Nakagawa et al., (2021)](https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13724)** to check for the evidence of publication bias in our data. First, we used a univariate meta regression model with the `sampling standard error` (i.e., square-root of the sampling variances) as a moderator to assess whether there exists any evidence of small-study effects in our dataset (modified `Egger's regression`). In univariate Egger's regression, a significant slope for SE (sqrt(vi)) indicates evidence for small-study effects **[(Bishop and Nakagawa, 2020)](https://doi.org/10.1111/1365-2664.13830)**.Second, we assessed a `time-lag bias` (i.e., decline in the effect sizes with time) by running a univariate meta-regression model with `publication year` as a moderator.


```{r, fig.width=11}

# univariate egger regressoin
data<- data %>% drop_na(d_pred_add)
egger_hedges_d <- rma.mv(yi = d_pred_add, d_var_pred_add, mods = ~sqrt(d_var_pred_add), test = "t", random = list(~1 | PR.ID, ~1 | ES.ID), method = "REML", data = data)

# plotting funnel plot
#funnel(egger_hedges_d, yaxis = "seinv", xlim = c(-200, 200), ylim = c(0.03, 0.047), level = c(90, 95, 99), shade = c("white", "gray55", "gray75"), refline = 0, legend = TRUE)


pred_pub_hedges_d <- predict.rma(egger_hedges_d)
pub_all_hedges_d <- data %>% drop_na(d_var_pred_add) %>% mutate(ymin = pred_pub_hedges_d$ci.lb, ymax = pred_pub_hedges_d$ci.ub,
                                    ymin2 = pred_pub_hedges_d$cr.lb, ymax2 = pred_pub_hedges_d$cr.ub, pred = pred_pub_hedges_d$pred) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sqrt(d_var_pred_add), y = d_pred_add, size = sqrt(1/d_var_pred_add))) + geom_point(shape = 21,
                                                                                                    fill = "grey90") + geom_smooth(aes(y = ymin2), method = "loess",
                                                                                                                                   se = FALSE, lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75, colour = "#0072B2") +
  geom_smooth(aes(y = ymax2), method = "loess", se = FALSE,
              lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75, colour = "#0072B2") + geom_smooth(aes(y = ymin),
                                                                            method = "loess", se = FALSE, lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75,
                                                                            colour = "#D55E00") + geom_smooth(aes(y = ymax), method = "loess",
                                                                                                              se = FALSE, lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75, colour = "#D55E00") +
  geom_smooth(aes(y = pred), method = "loess", se = FALSE,
              lty = "dashed", lwd = 1, colour = "black") + ylim(-100,
                                                                100) + xlim(0, 0.8) + labs(x = "sqrt(sampling variance)",
                                                                                           y = expression(paste("Mean effect size (Hedges' ", italic("d"), ")")), size = "Precision (1/SE)") + guides(fill = "none",
                                                                                                                                                                                                      colour = "none") + # themes
  theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = c(0, 1), legend.justification = c(0,
                                                                         1)) + theme(legend.direction = "horizontal") + theme(legend.background = element_blank()) +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10, colour = "black",
                                   hjust = 0.5, angle = 90))
# time lag bias
time_lag_effect_hedges_d <- rma.mv(yi = d_pred_add, d_var_pred_add, mods = ~Year, test = "t", 
                                   random = list(~1 | PR.ID, ~1 | ES.ID), method = "REML", data = data)



 
pred_time <- predict.rma(time_lag_effect_hedges_d)
time_lag_hedges_d <- data %>% drop_na(d_var_pred_add) %>% mutate(ymin = pred_time$ci.lb, ymax = pred_time$ci.ub,
                                     ymin2 = pred_time$cr.lb, ymax2 = pred_time$cr.ub, pred = pred_time$pred) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = d_pred_add, size = sqrt(1/d_var_pred_add))) + geom_point(shape = 21,
                                                                                    fill = "grey90") + 
  geom_smooth(aes(y = ymin2), method = "loess", se = FALSE, lty = "dotted",
              lwd = 0.75, colour = "#0072B2") + geom_smooth(aes(y = ymax2),
                                                            method = "loess", se = FALSE, lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75,
                                                            colour = "#0072B2") + geom_smooth(aes(y = ymin), method = "loess",
                                                                                              se = FALSE, lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75, colour = "#D55E00") +
  geom_smooth(aes(y = ymax), method = "loess", se = FALSE,
              lty = "dotted", lwd = 0.75, colour = "#D55E00") + geom_smooth(aes(y = pred),
                                                                            method = "loess", se = FALSE, lty = "dashed", lwd = 1, colour = "black") +
  ylim(-100, 100) + xlim(1998, 2021) + labs(x = "Year", y = "", size = "Precision (1/SE)")+ guides(fill = "none", colour = "none") +
  # themes
  theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = c(0, 1), legend.justification = c(0,
                                                                         1)) + theme(legend.direction = "horizontal") + theme(legend.background = element_blank()) +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10, colour = "black",
                                   hjust = 0.5, angle = 90))

(pub_all_hedges_d + time_lag_hedges_d)  + plot_annotation(tag_prefix = "(", tag_levels = "a", tag_suffix = ")")
```
**Figure 9 (main manuscript).** Meta-regression model results showing the moderating effects of (a) square-root of the sampling variances and (b) year of publication on mean combined effect size (Hedge's *d*). Orange dashed line represents 95% confidence intervals, blue dashed line 95% prediction intervals and each background point an effect size, with its size scaled by the precision of estimate (1/SE).
